title: Week - 1
text: Hi Everyone.

title: Linux - Environment Variables
text:
The .bashrc file is a shell script that automatically runs whenever you open a new interactive bash terminal session. It‚Äôs your personal configuration file located in your home directory (~/.bashrc) that sets up your shell environment.




MY_VAR="value"
PATH_TO_PROJECT="/home/user/project"
These variables are only available in the current shell and won‚Äôt be inherited by child processes.



export MY_VAR="value"
export PATH="$HOME/bin:$PATH"
export DATABASE_URL="localhost:5432"
Variables defined with export become environment variables that are automatically passed to all child processes and subshells.





PATH modifications: Add custom directories to your command search path
Project settings: Define project-specific environment variables
Aliases and shortcuts: Create convenient command shortcuts
Tool configuration: Set up development tools and their configurations







Purpose: Makes variables available to child processes and subshells
Scope: Variables flow downward from parent to child shells only
Usage: export VAR_NAME="value"





Purpose: Executes a script in the current shell (not a subshell)
Usage: source ~/.bashrc or . ~/.bashrc
Effect: Loads variables and functions into your current session without restarting the terminal




When you run a script with ./script.sh, exported variables disappear when the script ends because it runs in a subshell. When you use source script.sh, variables persist in your current shell.
Example workflow:
# Edit .bashrc
echo 'export MY_APP_PATH="/usr/local/myapp"' >> ~/.bashrc

# Apply changes without restarting terminal
source ~/.bashrc

# Now MY_APP_PATH is available
echo $MY_APP_PATH

title: OpenSource Contribution
text: To fetch someone else‚Äôs code from GitHub, fix an issue, and contribute your changes so they can merge your fixes, follow this standard Git workflow using Fork, Clone, Branch, Commit, Push, and Pull Request:

title: OpenSource Contribution
section: Steps to Contribute Code Fix on GitHub
text:
Steps to Contribute Code Fix on GitHub

1. Fork the Repository

Go to the repository page on GitHub where the original code is.
Click the ‚ÄúFork‚Äù button (top-right) to create your own copy of the repository under your GitHub account.



2. Clone the Forked Repository to Your Machine

On your GitHub fork page, click the green ‚ÄúCode‚Äù button and copy the repository URL.
In your terminal, run:

git clone <your-fork-repo-url>

This downloads the code to your local machine.



3. Create a New Branch for Your Changes

Change directory into the cloned repo:

cd <repo-name>

Create and switch to a new branch for your fix:

git checkout -b fix-issue-branch


4. Make Your Code Fixes

Edit the code locally to fix the issue.



5. Commit Your Changes

Stage the changed files:

git add .

Commit with a meaningful message:

git commit -m "Fix issue with XYZ"


6. Push Your Branch to Your Fork

Push your fix branch to your GitHub fork:

git push origin fix-issue-branch


7. Create a Pull Request (PR)

Go to your GitHub fork page.
You should see a prompt to create a pull request from your pushed branch.
Click ‚ÄúCompare & pull request‚Äù or ‚ÄúNew pull request.‚Äù
Add a descriptive title and description of the fix.
Submit the pull request so the original repo owner can review and merge your fix.


This process ensures your contribution is linked to your GitHub profile and gives the repo owner a clear way to review and merge your changes. It also preserves the original repository history cleanly.

title: Setup to connect Local ‚Äî Github
text:
Git : Locally you need to setup your github username and email
Github : Generate an SSH key and add the public key to your‚Äôs github account.




Make account in github.com and copy username and email

Open Terminal (Linux/Mac) or PowerShell/GitBash (Windows).

git config --global user.name "Your Github UserName"
git config --global user.email "your_github_email@example.com"




Open Terminal (Linux/Mac) or PowerShell/GitBash (Windows).
Run:
ssh-keygen
Press Enter through the prompts.
This generates two files, e.g., id_ed25519 (private) and id_ed25519.pub (public), usually in(exact path will be present in output of command ssh-keygen):
/home/username/.ssh/
Open id_ed25519.pub, copy its contents, and add it to your GitHub:

Settings ‚Üí Access ‚Üí SSH and GPG Keys ‚Üí New SSH Key
Select Authentication Key as the type.


So now you are ready to push your code on your github account

title: Install WSL in Windows
text:
We will use windows powershell to install wsl.



Open PowerShell
wsl --version or wsl.exe --version
If any above command shows wsl version 2 , then it is already installed





Search Turn Windows features on or off

Enable Virtual Machine Platform, Windows Hypervisor Platform, Windows Subsytem for Linux

Restart Computer (Not power on/off, click on restart)
Install WSL WSL-2 Setup
Switch to WSL-2 wsl --set-default-version 2




wsl --list --verbose
For Each Listed distribution
- wsl --unregister <DistributionName>
- Open Settings ‚Üí Apps ‚Üí Installed apps - Find each Linux distribution, click the three-dot menu, and select Uninstall




wsl --update

wsl --list --online

wsl --install Ubuntu-24.04 ‚Äì> Install Ubuntu

sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y ‚Äì> Update Ubuntu







Example





PS C:\Users\hrith> wsl --install Ubuntu-24.04
Downloading: Ubuntu 24.04 LTS
Installing: Ubuntu 24.04 LTS
Distribution successfully installed. It can be launched via 'wsl.exe -d Ubuntu-24.04'
Launching Ubuntu-24.04...
Provisioning the new WSL instance Ubuntu-24.04
This might take a while...

New password:
Retype new password:
passwd: password updated successfully
To run a command as administrator (user "root"), use "sudo <command>".
See "man sudo_root" for details.

[sudo] password for hrm:
Hit:1 http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu noble InRelease
Get:2 http://security.ubuntu.com/ubuntu noble-security InRelease [126 kB]

node install https://nodejs.org/en/download

nvm install 22

nvm list nvm use 22 nvm current

corepack enable yarn

corepack enable pnpm



Check
- nvm -v
- node -v
- npm -v npx -v
- pnpm -v
- yarn -v





Python VENV

python3 -m venv .venv ‚Äì> Copy error code and run sudo apt install python3.12-venv

PIPX

sudo apt install pipx

UV - Rust-based Python package installer

pipx install uv It will maintain isolation

LLM

pipx install llm ‚Äì> pipx ensurepath
Configure it

llm install llm-gemini or llm install llm-ollama
llm keys set gemini
llm -m gemini-2.0-flash 'Tell me fun facts about Mountain View'


MiniConda

Download .sh https://www.anaconda.com/download/success
bash <pathto .sh file>
conda config --set auto_activate_base false





sudo apt install build-essential

gcc ‚Äì> The C compiler

g++ ‚Äì> The C++ compiler


Check - gcc ‚Äìverison
- g++ ‚Äìversion




sudo apt install default-jdk

This command installs:

Java Development Kit (JDK) - Compiler, debugger, and development tools  
Java Runtime Environment (JRE) - Required to run Java applications  
Java Virtual Machine (JVM) - Core execution environment  

Configure JAVA_HOME Environment Variable

echo 'export JAVA_HOME="/usr/lib/jvm/default-java"' >> ~/.bashrc ## confirm the path first using below update-alternatiove‚Ä¶ command

restart shell

Install other versions of java

sudo apt install openjdk-17-jdk

Set Default Java/Javac installed version

sudo update-alternatives --config java
sudo update-alternatives --config javac



Check
- java --version
- javac --version
- echo $JAVA_HOME

title: Computer Boot Process
text:
Overview
Boot Process Steps
Partition Styles vs File Systems
Boot Process Summary
Frequently Asked Questions
Resources




The computer boot process transforms your computer from powered-off state to a fully operational system. This guide covers the essential steps and concepts needed to understand how computers start.





When you press the power button:

CPU executes the first program BIOS/UEFI

BIOS (Basic Input/Output System) - Legacy firmware (used in old computers)
UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) - Modern firmware





POST (Power-On Self Test):

Tests CPU, RAM, and storage devices
Validates hardware components

Boot Device Selection:

Reads Boot Order from firmware settings
GPT drives: Looks for EFI System Partition
MBR drives: Checks Master Boot Record in first sector




Common Bootloaders:
Linux or Window bootloader, both can scan and start any OS windows or linux.
- Linux: GRUB2, LILO, systemd-boot - Windows: Windows Boot Manager
Bootloader Tasks:

Scans partitions for installed operating systems
Presents boot menu (if multiple OS found)
Loads selected OS kernel into memory




Linux OS Boot:

Kernel loads and initializes hardware
systemd starts (modern init system)
System services launch
User login interface appears

Windows OS Boot:

NT Kernel (ntoskrnl.exe) loads
Hardware Abstraction Layer initializes
Registry and system drivers load
Session Manager starts Windows subsystems
Windows Logon presents login interface







Partition styles define how a drive is divided into sections:








Feature
MBR
GPT




Max Partitions
4 primary OR 3 primary + 1 extended
128 primary


Max Storage
2 TB
18+ exabytes


Boot Support
BIOS only
BIOS + UEFI






File systems determine how data is stored within partitions:



File System
OS
Use Case




NTFS
Windows
System drives, large files


FAT32
Cross-platform
USB drives, compatibility


ext4
Linux
Linux system drives


APFS
macOS
macOS system drives










Phase
Component
Purpose




1
Firmware (BIOS/UEFI)
Hardware initialization


2
POST
Hardware verification


3
Bootloader
OS selection and loading


4
OS Kernel
System initialization








flowchart LR
    A[Power On] --> B[Bios/Uefi]
    B --> C[POST Check]
    C --> D[LocateDrive]
    D --> E[Run Bootloader]
    E --> F{Select OS}
    F -->|Linux| G[Kernel + systemd]
    F -->|Windows| H[NT Kernel]
    G --> I[User Login]
    H --> I














Feature
BIOS
UEFI




Interface
Text-only
Graphical possible


Storage Support
2 TB max
No practical limit


Security
Basic
Secure Boot


Speed
Slower
Faster






Partition Style: Defines how the drive is divided (MBR vs GPT) File System: Defines how files are stored within each partition (NTFS, ext4, etc.)



Yes, by:

Installing each OS on separate partitions
Using a bootloader that detects all systems
Selecting which OS to boot at startup

title: Dual-Boot Setup Guide
text:
This guide will help you install another operating system (Linux) alongside your existing Windows installation.






Disclaimer





Do this at your own risk. Please watch various YouTube videos and proceed with dual boot only when you are 100% sure about the process.
If you want to minimize the risk:
1. Use External SSD/HDD to install Linux
- This will prevent almost 99% of any accidental damage to your main system
2. Install Kubuntu
- Since dual boot requires creating partitions
- Kubuntu has a Replace Partition option which avoids most of the headache






New SSD/HDD or at least 30GB free storage on your current Windows drive

If installing on the same SSD/HDD where Windows is installed:
I recommend shrinking at least a 30GB partition

How To Shrink Partition


Pendrive/USB drive (8GB or larger)
One ISO file of any Linux distribution. Kubuntu
Software to create a bootable USB drive. Ventoy





Insert your USB drive and run Ventoy
Format your USB drive with Ventoy to make it bootable
Just Copy and paste the Linux distribution ISO files into the USB drive
To be sure that iso file not got corrupted, you can run sha256sum and check both on local and server matches or not





Restart your computer
Go to BIOS/UEFI Settings

On HP laptops: restart and keep pressing the F10 key

Navigate to Boot Settings
Disable Secure Boot (you can re-enable it after installation)




Once your USB drive and laptop BIOS/UEFI settings are ready, proceed with the installation:

Restart your computer
Go to Boot Device Options

On HP laptops: keep pressing the F9 key

Choose your USB Drive
If using Ventoy:

It will ask which OS to boot (based on the ISOs you‚Äôve copied)

If using BalenaEtcher: it will directly boot into that particular OS
For Kubuntu installation:

Click on ‚ÄúInstall‚Äù
Select language, keyboard layout, etc.
When choosing where to install or configure partitions:

Choose Replace Partition ‚Äì> then Select the newly created(shrinked) 30GB partition
The installer will format two partitions

One for your Linux installation that you just selected
One will be EFI partition of windows(first partition in most cases)


Choose your username, password, etc., and proceed
Once installation is complete, your computer will automatically reboot or ask you to remove the USB drive and press Enter
Remove the USB drive and press Enter to reboot






Restart your computer
Go to BIOS/UEFI settings

You can enable Secure Boot if desired

Most importantly:

Navigate to Boot Settings
Change the boot order
Set Ubuntu/Linux as the first boot option






When you turn on your computer, you‚Äôll have the option to boot into Ubuntu or Windows
Important:

The first time you boot into Windows after installation:

You may see a blue screen asking for a BitLocker recovery key
You can easily log in with your Microsoft account and retrieve the password from BitLocker Recovery
This will only be asked once.







BitLocker Recovery
Kubuntu ISO
Ventoy




Shrink Partition

title: Computer Boot Process: Essential Guide
text:
Overview
Boot Process Steps
Partition Styles vs File Systems
Boot Process Summary
Frequently Asked Questions
Resources




The computer boot process transforms your computer from powered-off state to a fully operational system. This guide covers the essential steps and concepts needed to understand how computers start.





When you press the power button:

CPU executes the first program BIOS/UEFI

BIOS (Basic Input/Output System) - Legacy firmware (used in old computers)
UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) - Modern firmware





POST (Power-On Self Test):

Tests CPU, RAM, and storage devices
Validates hardware components

Boot Device Selection:

Reads Boot Order from firmware settings
GPT drives: Looks for EFI System Partition
MBR drives: Checks Master Boot Record in first sector




Common Bootloaders:
Linux or Window bootloader, both can scan and start any OS windows or linux.
- Linux: GRUB2, LILO, systemd-boot - Windows: Windows Boot Manager
Bootloader Tasks:

Scans partitions for installed operating systems
Presents boot menu (if multiple OS found)
Loads selected OS kernel into memory




Linux OS Boot:

Kernel loads and initializes hardware
systemd starts (modern init system)
System services launch
User login interface appears

Windows OS Boot:

NT Kernel (ntoskrnl.exe) loads
Hardware Abstraction Layer initializes
Registry and system drivers load
Session Manager starts Windows subsystems
Windows Logon presents login interface







Partition styles define how a drive is divided into sections:








Feature
MBR
GPT




Max Partitions
4 primary OR 3 primary + 1 extended
128 primary


Max Storage
2 TB
18+ exabytes


Boot Support
BIOS only
BIOS + UEFI






File systems determine how data is stored within partitions:



File System
OS
Use Case




NTFS
Windows
System drives, large files


FAT32
Cross-platform
USB drives, compatibility


ext4
Linux
Linux system drives


APFS
macOS
macOS system drives










Phase
Component
Purpose




1
Firmware (BIOS/UEFI)
Hardware initialization


2
POST
Hardware verification


3
Bootloader
OS selection and loading


4
OS Kernel
System initialization








flowchart LR
    A[Power On] --> B[Bios/Uefi]
    B --> C[POST Check]
    C --> D[LocateDrive]
    D --> E[Run Bootloader]
    E --> F{Select OS}
    F -->|Linux| G[Kernel + systemd]
    F -->|Windows| H[NT Kernel]
    G --> I[User Login]
    H --> I














Feature
BIOS
UEFI




Interface
Text-only
Graphical possible


Storage Support
2 TB max
No practical limit


Security
Basic
Secure Boot


Speed
Slower
Faster






Partition Style: Defines how the drive is divided (MBR vs GPT) File System: Defines how files are stored within each partition (NTFS, ext4, etc.)



Yes, by:

Installing each OS on separate partitions
Using a bootloader that detects all systems
Selecting which OS to boot at startup

title: WSL - Windows Subsytem for Linux
text:
We will use windows powershell to install wsl.



Open PowerShell
wsl --version or wsl.exe --version
If any above command shows wsl version 2 , then it is already installed





Search Turn Windows features on or off

Enable Virtual Machine Platform, Windows Hypervisor Platform, Windows Subsytem for Linux

Restart Computer (Not power on/off, click on restart)
Install WSL WSL-2 Setup
Switch to WSL-2 wsl --set-default-version 2




wsl --list --verbose
For Each Listed distribution
- wsl --unregister <DistributionName>
- Open Settings ‚Üí Apps ‚Üí Installed apps - Find each Linux distribution, click the three-dot menu, and select Uninstall




wsl --update

wsl --list --online

wsl --install Ubuntu-24.04 ‚Äì> Install Ubuntu

sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y ‚Äì> Update Ubuntu







Example





PS C:\Users\hrith> wsl --install Ubuntu-24.04
Downloading: Ubuntu 24.04 LTS
Installing: Ubuntu 24.04 LTS
Distribution successfully installed. It can be launched via 'wsl.exe -d Ubuntu-24.04'
Launching Ubuntu-24.04...
Provisioning the new WSL instance Ubuntu-24.04
This might take a while...
Create a default Unix user account: hrm
New password:
Retype new password:
passwd: password updated successfully
To run a command as administrator (user "root"), use "sudo <command>".
See "man sudo_root" for details.

hrm@bitnd:/mnt/c/Users/hrith$ sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y
[sudo] password for hrm:
Hit:1 http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu noble InRelease
Get:2 http://security.ubuntu.com/ubuntu noble-security InRelease [126 kB]







nvm install visit and run bash script https://github.com/nvm-sh/nvm

node install https://nodejs.org/en/download

nvm install 22

nvm list nvm use 22 nvm current

corepack enable yarn

corepack enable pnpm



Check
- nvm -v
- node -v
- npm -v npx -v
- pnpm -v
- yarn -v





Python VENV

python3 -m venv .venv ‚Äì> Copy error code and run sudo apt install python3.12-venv

PIPX

sudo apt install pipx

UV - Rust-based Python package installer

pipx install uv It will maintain isolation

LLM

pipx install llm ‚Äì> pipx ensurepath
Configure it

llm install llm-gemini or llm install llm-ollama
llm keys set gemini
llm -m gemini-2.0-flash 'Tell me fun facts about Mountain View'


MiniConda

Download .sh https://www.anaconda.com/download/success
bash <pathto .sh file>
conda config --set auto_activate_base false





sudo apt install build-essential

gcc ‚Äì> The C compiler

g++ ‚Äì> The C++ compiler


Check - gcc ‚Äìverison
- g++ ‚Äìversion




sudo apt install default-jdk

This command installs:

Java Development Kit (JDK) - Compiler, debugger, and development tools  
Java Runtime Environment (JRE) - Required to run Java applications  
Java Virtual Machine (JVM) - Core execution environment  

Configure JAVA_HOME Environment Variable

echo 'export JAVA_HOME="/usr/lib/jvm/default-java"' >> ~/.bashrc ## confirm the path first using below update-alternatiove‚Ä¶ command

restart shell

Install other versions of java

sudo apt install openjdk-17-jdk

Set Default Java/Javac installed version

sudo update-alternatives --config java
sudo update-alternatives --config javac



Check
- java --version
- javac --version
- echo $JAVA_HOME

title: Dual Boot
text:
This guide will help you install another operating system (Linux) alongside your existing Windows installation.






Disclaimer





Do this at your own risk. Please watch various YouTube videos and proceed with dual boot only when you are 100% sure about the process.
If you want to minimize the risk:
1. Use External SSD/HDD to install Linux
- This will prevent almost 99% of any accidental damage to your main system
2. Install Kubuntu
- Since dual boot requires creating partitions
- Kubuntu has a Replace Partition option which avoids most of the headache






New SSD/HDD or at least 30GB free storage on your current Windows drive

If installing on the same SSD/HDD where Windows is installed:
I recommend shrinking at least a 30GB partition

How To Shrink Partition


Pendrive/USB drive (8GB or larger)
One ISO file of any Linux distribution. Kubuntu
Software to create a bootable USB drive. Ventoy





Insert your USB drive and run Ventoy
Format your USB drive with Ventoy to make it bootable
Just Copy and paste the Linux distribution ISO files into the USB drive
To be sure that iso file not got corrupted, you can run sha256sum and check both on local and server matches or not





Restart your computer
Go to BIOS/UEFI Settings

On HP laptops: restart and keep pressing the F10 key

Navigate to Boot Settings
Disable Secure Boot (you can re-enable it after installation)




Once your USB drive and laptop BIOS/UEFI settings are ready, proceed with the installation:

Restart your computer
Go to Boot Device Options

On HP laptops: keep pressing the F9 key

Choose your USB Drive
If using Ventoy:

It will ask which OS to boot (based on the ISOs you‚Äôve copied)

If using BalenaEtcher: it will directly boot into that particular OS
For Kubuntu installation:

Click on ‚ÄúInstall‚Äù
Select language, keyboard layout, etc.
When choosing where to install or configure partitions:

Choose Replace Partition ‚Äì> then Select the newly created(shrinked) 30GB partition
The installer will format two partitions

One for your Linux installation that you just selected
One will be EFI partition of windows(first partition in most cases)


Choose your username, password, etc., and proceed
Once installation is complete, your computer will automatically reboot or ask you to remove the USB drive and press Enter
Remove the USB drive and press Enter to reboot






Restart your computer
Go to BIOS/UEFI settings

You can enable Secure Boot if desired

Most importantly:

Navigate to Boot Settings
Change the boot order
Set Ubuntu/Linux as the first boot option






When you turn on your computer, you‚Äôll have the option to boot into Ubuntu or Windows
Important:

The first time you boot into Windows after installation:

You may see a blue screen asking for a BitLocker recovery key
You can easily log in with your Microsoft account and retrieve the password from BitLocker Recovery
This will only be asked once.







BitLocker Recovery
Kubuntu ISO
Ventoy




Shrink Partition

title: Git
text:
Git is a distributed VCS(Version Control Software)
It store all code history/snapshots in .git folder
If you delete even all files, then you can recover all files from .git folder, because all codes are stored there with history




Install from official website git-scm







FLOW





work --> add/commit --> work --> add/commit --> ...
whenever we need we can do undo/redo



Create a folder for your project/work

git config --global init.defaultBranch main or later you may need to do git branch -m master main
git init create .git folder
create some files and write something
git add . add all files in staging area (except the files/folder name in .gitignore file)



git reset abc.txt will unstage, if something done by mistake


git commit -m "first commit" record this history in .git folder
now repeat 2nd, 3rd and 4th steps
If somewhere you want to go back to any specify commit

git log --one line
git checkout <commit_id>
git checkout main
git reset --soft <commit_id>

soft -> keeps your changes staged
mixed -> keeps your changes unstaged
hard -> ‚ö†Ô∏è discards everything after that commit









Just Previous Commit






git reset --soft HEAD~1

git reset --mixed HEAD~1

git reset --hard HEAD~1

title: Github
text:
GitHub is a cloud-based platform that hosts Git repositories.

It provides collaboration features like pull requests, issues, and project management.

Unlike Git (local), GitHub makes your code accessible online, enabling teamwork, backups, and sharing.


Git = a software (Version Control System)
GitHub = a cloud service for hosting programming repositories (like Google Drive, but for code)









Important



Git itself manages local repositories and pushes/pulls to/from remotes, but it does not create remote repositories on hosting platforms like Github.



The repository already exists on GitHub.

The repository does not yet exist on GitHub but locally exist.





Locate the repository on GitHub ‚Üí Click on <> Code ‚Üí Copy the SSH path.

Clone the repo into your local machine:
git clone git@github.com:myusername/myreponame.git
A folder myreponame will be created with all repo contents.
Work as usual ‚Üí edit files, then stage & commit changes:
git add .
git commit -m "your message"
Push your updates back to GitHub:
git push origin main

origin ‚Üí alias for the remote repo URL (e.g., GitHub).
main ‚Üí branch name (default branch, often main instead of master).








Go to GitHub ‚Üí New Repo.
Enter repository name ‚Üí e.g., myrepo.
Leave it empty (don‚Äôt add README, .gitignore, or license).

Note you can again follow scenario 1 where you can clone and then copy paste your new work and then commit and then push, or you can follow below steps.



From your project folder, run:
git remote add origin git@github.com:your-username/myrepo.git
(replace your-username with your actual GitHub username)



git branch -M main     # ensure current branch is 'main'
git push -u origin main

-u sets the upstream, so later you can simply use:
git push

Now your local repo is connected to GitHub. Check it online at: https://github.com/your-username/myrepo

title: Github
text:
Important



Git itself manages local repositories and pushes/pulls to/from remotes, but it does not create remote repositories on hosting platforms like Github.



The repository already exists on GitHub.

The repository does not yet exist on GitHub but locally exist.

title: Github
text:
Locate the repository on GitHub ‚Üí Click on <> Code ‚Üí Copy the SSH path.

Clone the repo into your local machine:
git clone git@github.com:myusername/myreponame.git
A folder myreponame will be created with all repo contents.
Work as usual ‚Üí edit files, then stage & commit changes:
git add .
git commit -m "your message"
Push your updates back to GitHub:
git push origin main

origin ‚Üí alias for the remote repo URL (e.g., GitHub).
main ‚Üí branch name (default branch, often main instead of master).

title: Github
text:
Go to GitHub ‚Üí New Repo.
Enter repository name ‚Üí e.g., myrepo.
Leave it empty (don‚Äôt add README, .gitignore, or license).

Note you can again follow scenario 1 where you can clone and then copy paste your new work and then commit and then push, or you can follow below steps.



From your project folder, run:
git remote add origin git@github.com:your-username/myrepo.git
(replace your-username with your actual GitHub username)



git branch -M main     # ensure current branch is 'main'
git push -u origin main

-u sets the upstream, so later you can simply use:
git push

Now your local repo is connected to GitHub. Check it online at: https://github.com/your-username/myrepo

title: Linux - Bash Scripting
text:
Variables
Variables store data and don‚Äôt require type declaration. Use $ to access variable values.
# Variable assignment (no spaces around =)
name="John"
age=25
path="/home/user"

# Access variables
echo $name
echo ${name}  # preferred for clarity


Data Types
Bash treats everything as strings by default, but supports:
# String
message="Hello World"

# Integer (for arithmetic)
num1=10
num2=20
result=$((num1 + num2))

# Array
fruits=("apple" "banana" "cherry")
echo ${fruits[0]}  # access first element
echo ${fruits[@]}  # all elements
echo ${#fruits[@]} # array length


Conditionals
Use if-then-else for decision making:
# Basic if statement
if [ $age -gt 18 ]; then
    echo "Adult"
elif [ $age -eq 18 ]; then
    echo "Just turned adult"
else
    echo "Minor"
fi

# String comparison
if [ "$name" = "John" ]; then
    echo "Hello John!"
fi

# File checks
if [ -f "file.txt" ]; then
    echo "File exists"
fi
Common operators:

-eq equal, -ne not equal
-gt greater than, -lt less than
-f file exists, -d directory exists



Loops

For Loop
# Loop through range
for i in {1..5}; do
    echo "Number: $i"
done

# Loop through array
for fruit in "${fruits[@]}"; do
    echo "Fruit: $fruit"
done

# Loop through files
for file in *.txt; do
    echo "Processing: $file"
done


While Loop
counter=1
while [ $counter -le 5 ]; do
    echo "Count: $counter"
    counter=$((counter + 1))
done



Text File Handling

Reading Files
# Read line by line
while IFS= read -r line; do
    echo "Line: $line"
done < "input.txt"

# Read entire file
content=$(cat "file.txt")


Writing Files
# Overwrite file
echo "Hello" > output.txt

# Append to file
echo "World" >> output.txt

# Write multiple lines
cat << EOF > config.txt
Setting1=value1
Setting2=value2
EOF


Text Processing
# Search in file
grep "pattern" file.txt

# Replace text
sed 's/old/new/g' file.txt

# Count lines
wc -l file.txt

# Extract columns
awk '{print $1}' file.txt



Functions
function greet() {
    echo "Hello $1!"
}

# Call function
greet "Alice"


Command Line Arguments
# Access arguments
echo "Script name: $0"
echo "First argument: $1"
echo "All arguments: $@"
echo "Number of arguments: $#"



Examples

Example 1: Basic System Info Script
#!/bin/bash
echo "=== System Information ==="
echo "Current user: $(whoami)"
echo "Current directory: $(pwd)"
echo "Date: $(date)"
echo "Disk usage:"
df -h | head -5


Example 2: File Processor
#!/bin/bash
input_file="data.txt"
output_file="processed.txt"

if [ -f "$input_file" ]; then
    echo "Processing $input_file..."
    
    # Count lines and words
    lines=$(wc -l < "$input_file")
    words=$(wc -w < "$input_file")
    
    echo "File Stats:" > "$output_file"
    echo "Lines: $lines" >> "$output_file"
    echo "Words: $words" >> "$output_file"
    echo "Content:" >> "$output_file"
    cat "$input_file" >> "$output_file"
    
    echo "Processing complete! Check $output_file"
else
    echo "Error: $input_file not found!"
fi


Example 3: Log File Analyzer
#!/bin/bash
log_file="/var/log/syslog"

echo "=== Log Analysis ==="
echo "Total lines: $(wc -l < "$log_file")"
echo "Error count: $(grep -c "error" "$log_file")"
echo "Warning count: $(grep -c "warning" "$log_file")"

# Recent errors
echo "Recent errors:"
grep "error" "$log_file" | tail -5
